sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Temani Afif)
articles.description: The CSS `border-image` property is one of those properties you undoubtedly know exists but may not have ever reached for. In this article, Temani Afif demonstrates different approaches for using `border-image` to create clever decorative accents and shapes.
articles.title: The Complex But Awesome CSS border-image Property

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Louis Lazaris)
articles.description: Useful front-end tools for CSS and JavaScript developers that were most popular last year and will help you speed up your development workflow. Let’s dive in!
articles.title: Top Front-End Tools Of 2023

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Atila Fassina)
articles.description: Are you ready for a little exercise of pulling a framework apart and putting the pieces back together? In this article, Atila Fassina explains how meta-frameworks have evolved around core libraries in their own unique ways.
articles.title: SolidStart: A Different Breed Of Meta-Framework

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: The View Transitions API is a new — but game-changing — feature that allows us to do the types of reactive state-based UI and page transitions that have traditionally been exclusive to JavaScript frameworks. In the second half of this mini two-part series, Adrian Bece expands on the demos from the first article to demonstrate how the View Transitions API can be used to transition not just elements between two states but the transition between full views and pages in single-page and multi-page applications.
articles.title: The View Transitions API And Delightful UI Animations (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s start into the new year with a little inspiration boost: wallpapers created with love by the community for the community. Happy 2024!
articles.title: The Magic Of New Beginnings (January 2024 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Juan Diego Rodríguez)
articles.description: JavaScript may be the most popular client-side language in the world, but it’s far from perfect and not without its quirks. Juan Diego Rodriguez examines several “absurd” JavaScript eccentricities and explains how they made it into the language as well as how to avoid them in your own code.
articles.title: Making Sense Of “Senseless” JavaScript Features

We’ve never understood how hunger works. That might be about to change. When you’re starving, hunger is like a demon. It awakens the most ancient and primitive parts of the brain, then commandeers…
articles.title: The Download: solving the mystery of hunger, and the climate-tech boom

articles.author: Adam Piore
articles.description: You haven’t seen hungry until you’ve seen Brad Lowell’s mice.  A few years ago, Lowell—a Harvard University neuro­scientist—and a postdoc, Mike Krashes, figured out how to turn up the volume on the drive for food as high as it can go. They did it by stimulating a bundle of neurons in the hypothalamus, an area…
articles.title: We’ve never understood how hunger works. That might be about to change.

articles.author: Allie Hutchison
articles.description: In September 2017, about two minutes before a magnitude 8.2 earthquake struck Mexico City, blaring sirens alerted residents that a quake was coming. Such alerts, which are now available in the United States, Japan, Turkey, Italy, and Romania, among other countries, have changed the way we think about the threat of earthquakes. They no longer…
articles.title: How machine learning might unlock earthquake prediction

articles.author: Brady Helwig, PJ Maykish
articles.description: In its final weeks, the Obama administration released a report that rippled through the federal science and technology community. Titled Ensuring Long-Term US Leadership in Semiconductors, it warned that as conventional ways of building chips brushed up against the laws of physics, the United States was at risk of losing its edge in the chip…
articles.title: We need a moonshot for computing

articles.author: David Rotman
articles.description: The surge of climate-tech startups seeking to reinvent clean energy and transform huge industrial markets is fueling optimism about our prospects for addressing climate change. Tens of billions are pouring into these venture-backed companies in just about every field you can imagine, from green steel to nuclear fusion. As I explain in “Climate tech is…
articles.title: Six takeaways from a climate-tech boom

articles.author: David Hambling
articles.description: When athletes or soldiers have a concussion, the most beneficial course of action is to simply get them off the playing field or out of the action so they can recover. Yet much about head injuries remains a mystery, including the reasons why some impacts result in concussion while others don’t. But new measuring devices…
articles.title: A high-tech mouthguard that might help prevent concussions

articles.author: Kathryn Miles
articles.description: What is the true value of a honeybee? A mountain stream? A mangrove tree?  Gretchen Daily, cofounder and faculty director of the Stanford Natural Capital Project, has dedicated her career to answering such complex questions. Using emerging scientific data and the project’s innovative open-source software, Daily and her team help governments, international banks, and NGOs…
articles.title: Meet the economist who wants the field to account for nature
